title-group.article-title: A progressive damage FEA model for glass/epoxy shell structures

article-meta.aff: Department of Mechanical Engineering & Aeronautics, University of Patras, Panepistimioupolis, Rio, Greece

author-notes.corresp: Theodore P Philippidis, Department of Mechanical Engineering & Aeronautics, University of Patras, P.O. Box 1401, GR 26504 Panepistimioupolis, Rio, Greece. Email: philippidis@mech.upatras.gr

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Constitutive models simulating anisotropic non-linear elastic behavior followed by progressive damage and failure prediction of moderately thick Glass Fiber Reinforced Plastic (GFRP) composite laminates were investigated in the present study. Stress analysis was performed using a Mindlin-Reissner shell formulation of a commercial code allowing for user-defined material constitutive equations. Progressive damage concepts based on inherent lamina non-linearity, numerous failure criteria, e.g. Puck, Chang, etc., and several property degradation strategies were implemented. In-plane mechanical properties of a glass/epoxy unidirectional composite, considered as the basic building block in the simulation, were thoroughly characterized in the frame of a comprehensive experimental program. Exhaustive model validation was performed by comparing numerical results with data from series of experimental tests on multidirectional laminates. Predicted damage pattern evolution along with macroscopic stress–strain behavior was found in very good agreement with strain gauge data and photos of failed test coupons.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Laminated structural composites of multidirectional (MD) stacking sequence are considered damage tolerant, accumulating severe matrix cracking through each layer thickness upon loading, without drastically affecting their ultimate load-carrying capacity. To take advantage of this, it is imperative to introduce methods and practices that describe mechanical property degradation, based on physical sense and experimental observations. Damage progression should be investigated in depth and failures that are not destructive should be tolerated in a ‘Fail Safe’ design approach. Extensive work was performed in this direction and various damage onset and propagation concepts were published by various research groups.

A comparison of the most ‘popular’ failure theories was attempted in the so-called ‘World Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE)’ followed by an extensive discussion on their effectiveness in predicting failure under complex stress states.1–4 The mechanics-level approach adopted by most of the research groups was meso-analysis, favored by micromechanics, which compares moderately with the experimental results.5,6 In ‘meso-mechanics,’ a unidirectional (UD) lamina is regarded as the basic building block and data from simple coupon tests in material symmetry axes are used to predict the response of the laminate. The presence of multiple cracks in a layer is modeled by appropriately modifying its mechanical properties. Damage is not considered independently from deformation analysis but coupled, progressively growing until final rupture.

One of the five leading methodologies in WWFE was proposed by Tsai and co-workers.7,8 The well-known quadratic failure tensor polynomial criterion was implemented in a linear plane-stress analysis, using the sign of the transverse normal strain to distinguish between fiber and matrix failure modes. An alternative way of decomposing the quadratic failure function was earlier proposed by Engelstad and Reddy.9

Bogetti et al.10,11 performed a 3D non-linear stress analysis using the maximum strain failure criterion. Stiffness constants associated with a particular failure mode were abruptly reduced in the failed layer to a negligible value. Stresses and strains were also set to zero. A 2D stress analysis implementing the maximum stress failure criterion was adopted by Zinoviev et al.12,13 The ply material behavior was considered as elastic-perfectly plastic while changes in fiber orientation due to high shear deformation and material relaxation were taken into account.

Puck and Shürmann,14,15 based on the Hashin concept16 and Mohr-Coulomb theory for the active failure plane, have introduced a more generalized phenomenological failure criterion and a concise strategy for mechanical property degradation to model damage accumulation. A similar approach, i.e. generalizing the Hashin concept for different criteria per failure mode and then using the appropriate property degradation rules, was earlier proposed by Chang and co-workers,17,18 Lessard and Shokrieh.19

The present work, an early version of which was presented in EWEC 2006,20 is part of a study conducted in the frame of an EC-funded project,21 aiming amongst others in the development of reliable design tools for very large-scale rotor blades. In this paper, a material model is introduced consisting of non-linear elastic properties, failure onset criteria and degradation strategies, so as to simulate structural response under static loads of thin to moderately thick composites.

A detailed characterization of mechanical properties in the symmetry coordinate system of a glass/epoxy (Gl/Ep) UD composite was performed through a comprehensive experimental program including static, fatigue and residual strength tests. The material system under examination, as most of FRP composites, exhibited highly non-linear behavior in some aspects. Stress–strain equations describing UD layer elastic response as developed by Richard and Blacklock22 were implemented in a shell element of a commercial Finite Element code.23 Several failure criteria, e.g. Puck, Lessard and Shokrieh etc., along with appropriate stiffness degradation scenarios were incorporated for progressive damage analyses.

Extensive and detailed validation of the numerical tool was performed by comparing numerical predictions with experimental results from axial tests performed on various MD laminated prismatic coupons, on- and off-axis loaded to failure at several directions.

sec.title: Constitutive equations and mechanical properties
sec.p: The building block of the laminates treated in this work is a transversely isotropic UD ply made of glass\epoxy. Characterization of constituent fiber and matrix materials along with cured composite technical characteristics, e.g. fiber volume fraction, glass transition temperature etc., is reported in Ref. [24]. Vacuum-assisted resin infusion molding was used for the manufacturing of a large number of plates, of various stacking sequences. In-plane mechanical properties of the UD lamina were obtained by means of an extensive experimental program consisting of static tests, both parallel and transverse to the fibers and also in shear. Details on experimental methods, specimen geometry and statistics of test results can be downloaded from various reports of Ref. [21].

The UD lamina exhibited a linear response in the fiber direction as expected. Elastic modulus E1 and major Poisson ratio v12 were obtained with a linear regression procedure on full stress–strain data sets, up to failure, from 56 UD coupons under tension or compression. In contrast, the elastic behavior of the material mainly in compression transversely to the fibers and under in-plane shear is highly non-linear. To account for this, incremental stress–strain relations were implemented, retaining the validity of the generalized Hooke law for each individual interval: (1)dσ1=E11-E2tE1ν122dɛ1+ν12E2t1-E2tE1ν122dɛ2dσ2=ν12E2t1-E2tE1ν122dɛ1+E2t1-E2tE1ν122dɛ2dσ6=G12tdɛ6 In the above equations, written with respect to the principal coordinate system of the UD ply, E1 and ν12 were considered constant throughout the static loading up to failure, while the tangential elastic moduli E2t, G12t were derived by adopting a non-linear equation introduced by Richard and Blacklock22: (2)σi=Eoiɛi[1+(Eoiɛiσoi)ni]1ni, i=2,6
By means of equation (2) one has: (3)E2t=dσ2dɛ2=Eo2[1-(σ2σo2)n2]1n2+1, G12t=dσ6dɛ6=Go12[1-(σ6σo6)n6]1n6+1

It was further proved from the evaluation of the experimental data that parameters Eo2,σo2,n2 for the transverse to the fiber elastic behavior differentiate between tension and compression. Numerical values for all the above constants were obtained by fitting the test data using non-linear regression analysis. The derived stress–strain curves were in agreement with the experimental data as it can be seen in Figures 1 and 2. Elastic property parameters were summarized in Table 1. Figure 1.
In-plane shear stress–strain curve of OB_UD Glass/Epoxy.
Figure 2.
Response of the OB_UD composite under transverse tension-compression.
Table 1.
Elasticity constants for the reference OB_UD glass/epoxy ply.
E1 = 37,950 (MPa) ν12 = 0.28
Eoi(MPa) σoi(MPa) ni
E2t(T) 15,035 75 3
E2t(C) 15,262 188 2.18
G12t 5,500 67 1.3

The mean values of experimentally defined in-plane failure stresses are given in Table 2. The symbols X, Y and S were used to denote strength in the fiber direction, the transverse and in-plane shear, respectively, while T and C, either as index or exponent, stand for tension and compression, respectively. Average ply thickness from measurements on UD [0] coupons was found equal to 0.95 mm. When stitched fabric [±45] was used for MD lay-ups, its ply thickness was taken equal to 0.292 mm to match experimentally measured average thickness of test coupons. Therefore, attention should be paid in the definition of the MD lay-up, [(±45/0)4/±45]T, in which the thickness of the [0] ply is more than triple that of the [45] layers. Table 2.
Strength values (in MPa) for the reference OB_UD glass\epoxy ply.
XT XC YT YC S
776 686 54 167 56

sec.title: Failure criteria
sec.p: To assess failure onset and define the respective failure modes in order to model damage propagation, a number of limit state conditions were implemented in the numerical routine. It is worthwhile noting that eventual corroboration of the theoretical predictions by test results, for the MD laminates, does not solely reflect back to the failure criterion but it is instead the entire constitutive model that should be accredited.

A direct comparison of only the various failure theories is not possible unless it is performed on UD plate test failure data from simple experiments with the best possible uniform stress field. Theoretical predictions in that case are derived using just the failure function of each criterion and the applied stress values.

In the case of MD laminates, failure prediction depends on several intermediate steps such as the appropriate stress analysis, the use of a specific failure theory, the effect of incipient damage on the material constitutive laws (in the case of meso-mechanics approach this is expressed by modifying accordingly the stiffness tensor) and the damage progression strategies. Finally, for the case that the stress analysis is performed using FEA, global failure conditions are necessary, e.g. failure of a coupon loaded axially in a displacement control mode is considered when the applied load reaches its maximum value.

In that respect, the failure criteria presented briefly below were not suggested as the most successful ones, nevertheless, when used in what was called “constitutive model,” including all above cited theoretical modules, gave the most successful predictions.

sec.title: Puck criterion
sec.p:
Based on the Hashin concept16 for different damage mechanisms and the Mohr-Coulomb hypothesis for brittle materials that fracture is exclusively triggered by stresses acting on the fracture plane, the criterion of Puck14,15 describes several failure modes with separate equations. For 2D plane stress analysis, five types of damage were assumed; two related with fiber fracture (FF), one in tension and another in compression. The other three concern matrix failure (inter-fiber fracture or IFF). Under tension (σ2 ≥ 0), cracks open transverse to the applied normal stresses (θfp = 0°, the angle subtended by the fracture plane and the vertical one to the layer plane), described as mode A. In compression, closed cracks are formed either transverse to the applied normal stresses (θfp = 0°), described as mode B, or an oblique rupture occurs with the fracture plane forming an angle θfp between ±45° and ±55°, described as mode C. Fiber and matrix failure effort or stress exposure factor, fE(FF) and fE(IFF), respectively, is calculated using the conditions shown in Table 3. Table 3.
Puck failure criteria for plane stress conditions.
Type of failure Failure mode Limit condition Condition for validity
Fiber fracture (FF) (T)
fE(FF)T=1XT[σ1+(E1Ef1vf12mσf-v12)σ2]≤1
[…]≥0
(C) (kinking)
fE(FF)C=1XC|[σ1+(E1Ef1vf12mσf-v12)σ2]|+(10γ12)2≤1
[…]≤0
Inter-fiber fracture (IFF) (T) Mode A θfp = 0°
fE(IFF)A=(σ6S)2+(1-p⊥|(+)YTS)2(σ2YT)2+p⊥|(+)σ2S+(σ1σ1D)4≤1
σ2≥0
(C) Mode B θfp = 0°
fE(IFF)B=1S((σ62)+(p⊥|(-)σ2)2+p⊥|(-)σ2)+(σ1σ1D)4≤1
σ2<00≤|σ2σ6|≤R⊥⊥A|σ6c|
(C) Mode C θfp ≠ 0° fE(IFF)C=[(σ62(1+p⊥⊥(-))S)2+(σ2YC)2](YC(-σ2))+(σ1σ1D)4≤1
σ2<00≤|σ6σ2|≤|σ6c|R⊥⊥A

Symbols used in these equations are as follows: Ef1 and v f1 are the elastic modulus and the Poisson ratio of the fibers. The term mσf accounts for a stress magnification effect caused by the different moduli of fibers and matrix which leads to an uneven distribution of the transverse stress σ2 from a micromechanical point of view; in the fibers it is slightly higher than in the matrix. For GFRP, a value of mσf≈1.3 is suggested by Puck and Shürmann.14 Term (10γ12)2 is a pure empirical factor accounting for shear contribution in fiber micro-buckling under compressive loads. For the variety of parameters implemented, guidelines and typical values are explicitly presented in Ref. [25]. The values used in the present implementation can be found in Ref. [20].

sec.title: Lessard and Shokrieh criterion
sec.p:
This criterion is based on Hashin theory too, discriminating between different failure modes with separate equations.19 To account for material non-linearity, shear stress over shear strength term in the Hashin criterion is replaced by a ratio of strain energy densities (SED) under in-plane shear, see Table 4. The integral in the numerator stands for the SED up to the specific load step while the integral in the denominator denotes the respective SED to failure, ɛ6u representing ultimate shear strain at failure. In the original formulation of the criterion, the cubic shear stress–strain relation proposed by Hahn26 was adopted in calculating the SED. In the present study, however, equation (2) was implemented since a third-order polynomial cannot accurately describe the behavior in shear of the specific material investigated. The analytical expressions of the limit conditions are shown in Table 4. Table 4.
Lessard & Shokrieh failure criteria for plane stress conditions.
Type of failure Failure mode Limit condition Condition for validity
Fiber fracture (FF) (T)
fE(FF)T=(σ1XT)2+∫0ɛ6σ6dɛ6∫0ɛ6uσ6dɛ6≤1
σ1≥0
(C)
fE(FF)C=(σ1XC)2≤1
σ1≤0
Inter-fiber fracture (IFF) Fiber-Matrix shearing
fE(IFF)S-C=(σ1XC)2+∫0ɛ6σ6dɛ6∫0ɛ6uσ6dɛ6≥1
σ1≤0
(T)
fE(IFF)T=(σ2YT)2+∫0ɛ6σ6dɛ6∫0ɛ6uσ6dɛ6≥1
σ2≥0
(C)
fE(IFF)C=(σ2YC)2+∫0ɛ6σ6dɛ6∫0ɛ6uσ6dɛ6≥1
σ2≤0

sec.title: Combined failure criteria
sec.p:
The theoretical predictions derived by means of the material model implementing Puck failure criteria were shown to perform very well in most of the cases studied. As it will be demonstrated however in a subsequent section, for some configurations, as e.g. prediction of stress–strain behavior of a [(∓45/90)4/∓45]T tensile coupon, the results were not satisfactory. The combined action of high normal stresses in the fiber direction and very high shear strains, as a result of stiffness degradation implied by the material model, affect failure prediction. To cope with this problem, a combined failure criterion was formed. All IFF failure criteria of Puck were maintained while modified FF criteria, in tension and compression, of Chang and Lessard18 were introduced, see Table 5. Table 5.
Modified FF criteria.
Type of failure Failure mode Limit condition Condition for validity
Fiber fracture (FF) and/or fiber matrix shearing (T)
fE(FF)T=(σ1XT)2+(ɛ6ɛ6u)2≤1
σ1≥0
(C)
fE(FF)C=(σ1XC)2+(ɛ6ɛ6u)2≤1
σ1≤0
The second term in the above equations is the ratio of instant shear strain, i.e. at the load increment in which the limit condition is first satisfied and its ultimate value.

sec.title: Property degradation strategies
sec.p: Material post-failure modelling is crucial for laminate strength calculation purposes, especially in matrix-dominated lay-ups. Sudden stiffness degradation after failure onset is further increasing inherent material non-linearity. However, depending on the predicted damage mode and the chosen failure approach, different deterioration strategies were applied.

sec.title: Gradual stiffness degradation model
sec.p: A progressive stiffness degradation model, already introduced by Puck and Shürmann,14 is implemented in a modified form in the numerical procedure presented in this work. A degradation factor, η≤1, being a function of stress or strain is introduced multiplying the elasticity moduli, simulating the growing damage: (4)η=1-ηr1+c(ɛ2ɛ2fail-1)ξ+ηr

Originally in Ref. [14], calculation of the degradation factor η is directly related to the failure effort fE(IFF) for matrix cracking. In the present study, however, tangent instead of secant elasticity is implemented and it was found efficient to replace fE(IFF) by the ratio ɛ2ɛ2fail, where ɛ2 stands for the transverse to the fibers strain at the current load step while ɛ2fail accounts for strain at the failure onset point. The term ηr specifies the residual stiffness value after damage (matrix cracking) accumulation reaches its saturation level. A value of ηr equal to zero was assumed herein for all failure modes.

The parameters c and ξ of equation (4) were tuned to achieve optimal stress–strain prediction for a particular MD material system under tensile loading (see section ‘Prediction of strength and stress–strain curves’, laminate MD60), where matrix cracks accumulation dominate material performance. The obtained parameters for the FEA model were found equal to c = 5 and ξ = 3. In all remaining calculations, these values were considered to be constant for all laminate lay-ups. No theoretical background exists to establish parameters invariance; however, there is enough experimental evidence that the model successfully predicts material strength and stress–strain response.

The difference (ɛ2ɛ2fail-1) in equation (4) increases with load, thus, reducing the values of η. At the same time, it can be considered as a representative parameter of matrix crack accumulation. The degradation factor is calculated at every load step. For intact material, (fE(IFF) < 1), it is considered constant: η = 1. The numerical solution continues to the next load step multiplying stiffness constants by 1. Otherwise, if fE(IFF) ≥ 1, the layer has reached its crack onset point. Depending on the failure mode, the values of the corresponding elasticity moduli, obtained from the material non-linear response, are multiplied by the degradation factor η, and the solution continues to the next load step.

Since failure mode A (σ2≥0) consists of matrix cracks that tend to open, it is assumed that load-bearing capacity normal to the crack is reduced along with the ability of shear load transfer. Hence, the transverse Young modulus, E2, and the shear modulus, G12, were considered to degrade simultaneously. The same degradation factor, η, multiplies both engineering elastic constants, the values of which were derived at each load step according to the non-linear (NL) models previously introduced.

In damage mode B, matrix cracks whose planes are also normal to the ply and parallel to the fibres orientation tend to close during loading (σ2≤0), due to compressive stresses. Still, a certain sliding movement of the crack faces relative to each other is expected to occur caused by the shear stresses. A degradation factor is applied only in the shear modulus value. In the ‘explosive’ mode C, the transverse Young modulus, E2, and the shear modulus, G12, are both set to a very small value (multiplied by 10−10).

When fiber breakage (fE(FF) ≥ 1) occurs, either in tension or compression, all stiffness moduli are multiplied by 10−10 simultaneously. Failure is considered when the specimen cannot sustain further load increase and especially for the case of axial tests, when the macroscopic σ-ɛ curve tends to become horizontal. The stiffness degradation scenario is summarized in Table 6, assuming that calculations take place at the ith load increment. Table 6.
Progressive stiffness degradation model (PSD).
Failure mode
FF(T) or FF(C)
E1(i+1)=10-10·E1(Failure)E2(i+1)=10-10·E2(Failure)G12(i+1)=10-10·G12(Failure)ν12(i+1)=10-10·ν12(Failure)
IFF(A)
E2(i+1)=η(i)E2(NL)(i)G12(i+1)=η(i)G12(NL)(i)
IFF(B)
G12(i+1)=η(i)G12(NL)(i)
IFF(C)
E2(i+1)=10-10·E2(Failure)G12(i+1)=10-10·G12(Failure)

sec.title: Ply discount’ model for stiffness degradation
sec.p:
The degradation model implemented in the numerical procedure presents some differences with that introduced by Lessard and Shokrieh19 although it retains the concept of sudden zeroing instead of progressive stiffness degradation, see Table 7. The degradation of the elastic moduli required by the ‘ply discount’ approach, to maintain numerical stability, is realized by multiplying their actual values with 10−10 at failure onset. Table 7.
‘Ply discount’ degradation model (PDD).
Failure mode
FF(T) or FF(C)
E1(i+1)=10-10·E1(Failure)E2(i+1)=10-10·E2(Failure)G12(i+1)=10-10·G12(Failure)ν12(i+1)=10-10·ν12(Failure)
Fiber-matrix shearing
G12(i+1)=10-10·G12(Failure)
IFF(A)
E2(i+1)=10-10·E2(Failure)G12(i+1)=10-10·G12(Failure)
IFF(B)

sec.title: FEA model implementation
sec.p:
Numerous FEA models were implemented for different coupon geometries and lay-up configurations. The verification tests were performed on axial coupons cut at various directions from an MD plate of [(±45/0)4/±45]T stacking sequence. The geometric characteristics and the number of elements used for each FE model are summarized in Table 8. The mesh density was the result of a convergence study in which static failure analyses were conducted for a prismatic coupon implementing a uniform rectangular mesh. In a first iteration, an initial number of elements was considered and then, the same load case was solved again with half this element number. If the difference between strength predictions from the two analyses was less than 1%, further reduction of the total element number was realized (dividing by a factor of 2). The procedure was repeated until fulfillment of the aforementioned condition. If on the other hand the second analysis diverged from the starting solution, the procedure was repeated by doubling the number of elements until convergence. Table 8.
Specimen dimensions used for the various FE models.
[±45]S MD0, MD10, MD60 MD90(T) MD90 (C)
Elements 1728 752 1984 456
Layers 4 14 14 14
Width (mm) 25 25 25 10
Length (mm) 250 150 300 126
Gauge length (mm) 150 40 150 12
Thickness. (mm) 3.8 6.72 6.72 6.72

The acronym MDθ (θ in deg.) indicates an MD off-axis coupon cut at an angle θ, clockwise with respect to the [0] layers fibre direction of the basic MD lay-up. The x-axis of the coupon is along its length, the coordinate system being considered right handed. Then, for example, MD10 denotes a non-symmetric, non-balanced stacking sequence of [(+55/−35/10)4/+55/−35]T. In addition to the MDθ experiments, axial tensile tests were also performed on symmetric [±45]S coupons to study matrix failure modes where in-plane shear stress is dominant.

In all specimens, nodal displacements were all constrained along the x-axis in one tab region (considered as fixed) while coupon movement was limited in the y-direction through node constraints in the centreline, allowing Poisson ‘breathing.’ Displacement was incrementally applied on the nodes of the other tab area (considered as moving), see Figure 3, where y-axis displacement was also constrained along the centreline. Figure 3.
FEA model of an multidirectional (MD) coupon and boundary conditions.

Strains and stresses were calculated through a layer by layer, piece-wise linear analysis, in ANSYS commercial FEM code. Displacement was applied in small increments, ca. an average value of 100 steps up to failure, so as to accurately simulate material non-linear behaviour and avoid numerical convergence problems.

A shell element (SHELL181) implementing first-order shear deformation theory (Mindlin-Reissner) was selected, allowing for user-defined constitutive equations, through a FORTRAN routine, compatible with the specific element.23 Material non-linear behaviour, incremental stress–strain analysis, failure criteria and stiffness updating schemes due to degradation form the ‘constitutive model.’ These modules were combined and included in the aforementioned routine, which subsequently was compiled with ANSYS core code, resulting in a new ANSYS executable file for every progressive damage model.

In the frame of this study, numerous constitutive progressive damage models were evaluated. This was helped by the structure of the numerical routine, which served the purpose of easily replacing non-linear constitutive equations, tangent or secant elasticity, failure criteria and stiffness degradation rules. Nevertheless, results from only three ‘constitutive models,’ the most effective, are presented herein. All of them rely on incremental stress–strain laws to model non-linearity. In Model A, Puck failure criteria and the gradual stiffness degradation procedure were implemented. The ‘ply discount’ approach for property degradation along with Lessard and Shokrieh failure criteria were included in Model B. Model C is similar to A as far as it concerns stiffness degradation but implements the combined failure criteria, i.e. Puck (IFF) limit conditions and the modified Chang and Lessard (FF) criteria as previously introduced.

sec.title: Prediction of strength and stress–strain curves
sec.p:
An extensive comparison between numerically calculated stress–strain curves up to failure and experimental data was performed for a variety of MD coupons, see Table 9. In most of the cases investigated, failure stresses were satisfactorily predicted by all three material models. This was especially true for stacking sequences where the final failure mode was fiber-dominated, e.g. tension or compression of MD0, 10, 60. Table 9.
Ultimate axial stress: Numerical predictions vs. experimental data (in MPa).
Coupon lay-up Loading Exp. Model A Model B Model C
[±45]s T 112 114 114 109
[(±45/0)4/±45]T (MD0) C −444 −458 −460 −461
[(±45/0)4/±45]T (MD0) T 520 508 510 509
[(+55/−35/10)4/+55/−35]T (MD10) C −433 −471 −482 −454
[(+55/−35/10)4/+55/−35]T (MD10) T 487 531 532 484
[(−75/+15/60)4/−75/+15]T (MD60) T 196 213 193 189
[(−75/+15/60)4/−75/+15]T (MD60) C −251 −253 −271 −242
[(∓45/90)4/∓45]T (MD90) T 143 242 220 165
[(∓45/90)4/∓45]T (MD90) C −195 −267 −299 −224

Nevertheless, numerical predictions concerning both strength and overall stress–strain behavior were also satisfactory for matrix-dominated lay-ups as for example for the [±45]S coupon under tension, see Figure 4. The results were shown to agree well with the experimental strain measurements in the axial and transverse directions in the middle of the coupon. A few only experimental stress–strain curves from those shown in Figure 1 were included in Figure 4 to keep the picture clear. The theoretical predictions were almost overlapping with Model C being slightly more conservative, see first row of Table 9. Figure 4.
Tensile stress–strain behavior of a [±45]s coupon.

The experimental stress–strain curves were derived by measuring with strain gauges placed back to back at the centers of coupon surfaces. The calculated stress for the numerical predictions was derived by adding all nodal forces in a cross section and dividing by its area. Further, the numerical strain value was derived as the average of the elements in the area where the real strain gauges were bonded.

As another example, the MD60 coupon, of asymmetric and unbalanced lay-up, composed of [−75], [15] and [60] plies was considered. In these particular axial tests, the stress–strain behavior is seriously affected by damage accumulation and matrix-dominated material non-linearity. The accurate modeling of these actions has a major effect on the numerical predictions. Nevertheless, coupon rupture is activated by fiber failure in the [15] off-axis layers, as numerically predicted and experimentally verified.

A comparison of numerical predictions and results from the tensile tests is presented in Figure 5. Models A and C simulated successfully coupon stress–strain curve while model B prediction deviated from the experimental data at an applied stress of around 90 MPa. Since only matrix cracks were expected at this particular stress level, it was obviously the property degradation strategy of model B, i.e. the ply discount approach that was proved conservative for this specific loading case. Nevertheless, Model B yielded the best coupon strength prediction. Model C, based on optimized (tuned) degradation parameters, simulated accurately coupon response, providing also a good estimation of specimen ultimate stress, as seen in the 6th row of Table 9. Model A strength prediction was the most optimistic. Figure 5.
Tensile response of a MD60 laminate.

Discrepancies between the numerical calculations and the test data were observed in the case of the MD90 coupon, [(∓45/90)4/∓45]T. Its failure was matrix-dominated either in tension or compression. The laminate response was highly nonlinear as shown in Figure 6. Model B estimated more effectively the stress–strain curve indicating that ‘ply discount’ degradation scenario proved adequate for the purpose. Nevertheless, its predictions for the ultimate tensile or compressive stress were non-conservative. Figure 6.
Tensile response of the MD90 laminate.

On the other hand, Model C yielded a satisfactory strength prediction, see Table 9, due to the activation of fiber-matrix shearing limit conditions shown in Table 5. Models A and B overestimated coupon strength since after extensive IFF mode A failures and related stiffness degradation, stresses σ1 in the fiber direction of [±45] layers continue to increase until reaching the respective failure limit. This behavior contradicts with the experimental observations where due to extended matrix cracking transverse to the [±45] fibers, these cannot carry further load and final failure is induced by 3D interlaminar effects and delaminations. Nevertheless, this is a shortcoming of the stress analysis approach, i.e. shell theory formulation.

sec.title: Failure pattern evolution
sec.p: A complementary path of model validation and refinement, besides the already presented comparison with coupon stress–strain behavior and strength, is to study the failure pattern in the gauge length area of the coupon. Especially, its evolution with load, as well as its final configuration, could be eventually correlated with experimental observation and yield valuable insight on precise tuning of constitutive formulations. To cope with space limitations, results only from Model C are presented herein, since its strength predictions were more accurate in the average.

sec.title: Tension of an ISO 14129 [±45]S glass\epoxy coupon
sec.p:
The specimen dimensions and its associated FEA model characteristics are given in Table 8. Damage propagation in both plies, [+45] and [−45], as a function of increasing load is presented in Figure 7. Half of the [±45]s coupon gauge length and the left tab area are shown. Figure 7.
Damage evolution with load in the plies of a [±45]S coupon under tension: (a) 65 MPa, (b) 87.3 MPa, (c) 108 MPa, (d) 109 MPa.

Tensile matrix cracks, IFF mode A, were simultaneously presented in both layers near the tabs, at 60% of the ultimate load. Damage spreads all over coupon gauge length until catastrophic failure, which is expected when fiber-matrix shearing occur through the specimen width, in all plies. At that time, axial and transverse to the loading axis stress–strain curves become horizontal verifying that no further load can be sustained.

The predicted, widespread, tensile matrix cracks were also observed in the surface layers of failed coupons, as that shown in Figure 8. Moreover, the numerical prediction for rupture near the tab area compares also well with the experimentally observed failure mode. Nevertheless, delamination developed in the test specimen cannot be predicted by the FEA model since it is related with 3D out-of-plane effects. It is true, however, that for this Gl/Ep material no early delaminations were detected and they were only manifested at coupon rupture. Figure 8.
Failed ISO 14129 standard [±45]s coupons under tensile loading.

sec.title: Compression of the MD0 coupon
sec.p:
On-axis compressive loading, i.e. loading parallel to the [0]-layer fibers direction, of an MD coupon, of [(±45/0)4/±45]T stacking sequence, was simulated next. Failure maps of the three outermost layers, at the ultimate load level, are presented in Figure 9. Measured axial stress–strain curves along with numerical predictions by FEA Model C, calculated in the middle of the specimen, were also included. Material stress–strain behavior, coupon strength and damage mechanisms are in good agreement with the experiment, see also Figure 10. Figure 9.
Simulated failure pattern of a MD0 coupon in compression.
Figure 10.
Failed MD0 coupon in compression.

Damage sets-in at 80% of the predicted compressive strength in the form of tensile matrix cracking, IFF mode A, and propagates in the [0] layers along the coupon width (fiber splitting). The stress concentration due to boundary conditions and matrix cracking near the tab areas enhances fiber compressive damage. The specimen is considered as failed when fiber rupture spreads along the specimen width and the stress–strain curve becomes horizontal. Extended fiber breakage is predicted in the middle of the coupon caused from fiber kinking in the UD [0] layer along with explosive mode C failures in the two upper layers. A direct comparison between numerically simulated pattern and test-failed specimen could be performed since both catastrophic modes, i.e. FF(C) and IFF(C), were distinguishable in Figures 9 and 10. An ultrasonic C-scan test could further enhance the assessment.

sec.title: Tension of MD coupon off-axis loaded at 60°
sec.p:
The stacking sequence of the MD60 coupon is [(−75/+15/60)4/−75/+15]T where the [60] layers correspond to the UD plies and the [−75], [15] to the off-axis layers of the stitched biaxial fabric. Since the lay-up is asymmetric and unbalanced, the short length of the coupon along with the way it is gripped in the test rig generates structural couplings that result in an uneven deformation field, partly seen in the deformed boundary of the coupon in Figure 11. As it can be deduced, the implemented numerical scheme, i.e. Model C, predicts satisfactorily coupon stress–strain behavior up to failure, estimating very well the specimen strength as well. Figure 11.
Failure map at rupture of an MD60 coupon in tension.

Tensile matrix cracks, IFF mode A, were predicted to initiate simultaneously in the [−75] and the [60] layers at 30% of the ultimate tensile stress. Well after first-ply-failure has occurred, fiber splitting, i.e. tensile matrix cracks and fiber breakage, were predicted in the [15] plies. According to the FEM calculations, coupon rupture is caused when fiber-matrix shearing failure in the 15 degree plies is spread along the coupon’s width. Then, the stress–strain curve turns to become horizontal giving a clear indication of laminate strength. Prediction of failure maps in the upper three layers of the laminate is presented in Figure 11.

It is interesting to note in Figure 11 the regions where compressive fiber failures were predicted in the [60] ply, near the tab corners, along with ‘explosive’ IFF mode C. The latter are probably responsible for the delaminated band, inclined at 60°, underneath the outermost [−75] layer shown in Figure 12, where the experimentally observed failure patterns were presented. At the same figure, a band of split fibers due to IFF(A) matrix cracks in the [15] outer ply were clearly shown, validating in the best way the numerical predictions of Figure 11. Figure 12.
Failed MD60 coupon faces. Upper [−75] and lower [15] plies.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: An anisotropic, non-linear constitutive model, implementing progressive damage concepts, was formulated in a moderately thick shell element of a commercial FEM code. In-plane stress–strain response and mechanical properties were fully characterized for a UD Gl/Ep composite; under in-plane shear, in tension, compression parallel and transverse to the fibers direction.

The constitutive model consists of three modules. First, the stress–strain relations, where incremental piece-wise linear formulation with tangent elasticity was adopted to model the non-linear elastic response. Second, the limit conditions where three different failure theories were selected. These are the Puck criteria,14,15 Lessard and Shokrieh19 and a failure scenario combining the IFF modes of Puck and modified the FF modes of Chang and Lessard.18 Finally, stiffness degradation strategies where two different formulations representative of the ‘ply discount’ and the ‘gradual degradation’ approaches were introduced.

Three different constitutive models, A to C, were implemented in the computational procedure. Numerical simulations were performed for coupons made of MD laminates under axial tensile or compressive loading. The performance of all three constitutive models was satisfactory and comparison of their numerical predictions with experimental data was favorable. Model C, implementing a combination of IFF criteria by Puck and a modified set of FF and fiber-matrix shearing, along with gradual stiffness degradation concepts exhibited the most robust performance.

The thick shell FE model can neither take into account the expected high interlaminar stresses at coupon-free edges nor the 3D stress field developed near the gripping area. However, for the Gl/Ep composite considered, even for asymmetric and unbalanced stacking sequences, it predicts very well coupon stress–strain response, even for cases of highly non-linear response, as the MD60, calculating the failure load and strain with fine precision. Discrepancies are expected wherever dominant 3D effects are present, e.g. early delaminations, as probably in the MD laminate investigated, off-axis loaded at 90° under compression. Nevertheless, in most of the cases where numerical predictions were compared with experimental results, failure patterns were corroborated satisfactorily by photos of failed coupons.

The present model is computationally less expensive than a 3D FEA approximation, and the solution procedure is fast enough allowing simulations of large models in a reasonable time. These characteristics suggest that the computational routine could be further enhanced to cover fatigue loading of shell structures such as large wind turbine rotor blades.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This study was partially funded by the European Commission in the framework of the research programme “Reliable Optimal Use of Materials for Wind Turbine Rotor Blades” (OPTIMAT BLADES), contract No: ENK6-CT-2001-00552 and in part by the General Secretariat of Research and Technology (GSRT) of the Greek Ministry of Development, contract No. F.K. 6660.

sec.title: Conflict of Interest
sec.p: None declared.
